annotations.message: Asterisks in the source are insecure
annotations.help_text: This source allows potentially unsafe resources to be loaded from anywhere.
annotations.remediation_tip: Remove any instances of the asterisk character (*) that are by itself from your content security policy.

annotations.help_text: The "data" source may allow the loading of unsafe resources.
annotations.remediation_tip: Remove "data:" from the source list in your content security policy.

annotations.help_text: Unsafe-inline is vulnerable to cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks.
annotations.remediation_tip: Remove the "unsafe-inline" keyword from your content security policy.

annotations.help_text: The Content-Security-Policy (CSP) fails to specify a reporting location through a reporting directive (report-to or report-uri).
annotations.remediation_tip: Include a reporting directive with a valid location or group.

annotations.help_text: No explicit hosts are specified for source-list directives or "unsafe" keywords are used (unsafe-inline or unsafe-eval).
annotations.remediation_tip: Do not use any "unsafe" keywords and use explicit hosts for any source-list directives.

annotations.help_text: This Content-Security-Policy (CSP) has issues that possibly makes it insecure.
annotations.remediation_tip: Remove any instances of "unsafe-" directives and "blob, data, filesystem" sources. Ensure your CSP directives are correctly configured. Learn more at W3C CSP.

remediations.help_text: The implementation of these header(s) do not follow security best practices.
remediations.remediation_tip: Ensure your headers are implemented correctly, as outlined in RFC-7231. Your headers should not permit caching of encrypted content. They should also have specific permissions (as opposed to using wildcards or other generalizations) and be formatted properly.

results.comments:
Joe Ammond said: "This is a vendorprovided application, and we have minimal control over the configuration. We have reached out to the vendor GitHub and this is their response:"Thanks for writing in. The current settings are by design and have been reviewed by our engineering and security teams, and are to enable our use of inline styles and images. We are aware that some security scanners show a warning for this configuration."" at 2022-09-14 16:37 UTC;
Hannah Brand said: "Issue being worked by Jennifer Caby" at 2023-09-05 19:55 UTC

remediations.help_text: This certificate has expired. While the traffic to the host is still encrypted, it may be vulnerable to new attacks.
remediations.remediation_tip: Replace the certificate with one that has a valid expiration date. Reference the ‘Key Evidence’ field for certificate’s specific location in your network (IP address, domain, etc.). Once located, identify the finding by the certificate serial number. Note that a new certificate serial number is generated when generating a new certificate, which creates a new finding.

diligence_annotations.app_description:
Stay connected with your financial goals – anytime, anywhere – with our Edward Jones app. 

Your financial information is at your fingertips with features allowing you to:

  •	View your account holdings, performance, activity and more
  •	Connect accounts to view balances held outside of Edward Jones
  •	Track progress toward your goals
  •	Message and share documents with your Edward Jones team
  •	Deposit checks and transfer funds
  •	View and sign documents related to your Edward Jones accounts

Also, security is built in to ensure your information is protected.
diligence_annotations.app_release_notes: This update includes minor bug fixes and improvements to the user experience.
diligence_annotations.check_description:
Traffic is analyzed to determine if any sensitive data is transmitted insecurely over the network without encryption.

For this check, instances of the Last Name were searched across any intercepted traffic.
diligence_annotations.remediation:
Enforce the use of SSL/TLS for all transport channels in which sensitive information, session tokens, or other sensitive data is going to be communicated to a backend API or web service.

Properly validate the SSL/TLS certificate to ensure it is signed by a trusted certificate authority (CA) as well as contains the correct hostname.

An even more secure approach is to use Certificate Pinning to mitigate the possibility of SSL/TLS weaknesses. Certificate Pinning is making sure the client checks the server's certificate against a known copy of that certificate. Simply bundle your server's certificate inside your application, and make sure any SSL/TLS request first validates that the server's certificate exactly matches the bundle's certificate.

For some apps, Certificate Pinning may be impossible to do. If your app allows users to enter in their own domain names to connect to services, then you have no opportunity to embed that certificate. However, if your app is intended to connect to a known server, or set of servers, you have all the information you need to guarantee that client is indeed talking directly to the server and without a man in the middle eavesdropping.

remediations.remediation_tip:
Enforce the use of SSL/TLS for all transport channels in which sensitive information, session tokens, or other sensitive data is going to be communicated to a backend API or web service.

Properly validate the SSL/TLS certificate to ensure it is signed by a trusted certificate authority (CA) as well as contains the correct hostname.

An even more secure approach is to use Certificate Pinning to mitigate the possibility of SSL/TLS weaknesses. Certificate Pinning is making sure the client checks the server's certificate against a known copy of that certificate. Simply bundle your server's certificate inside your application, and make sure any SSL/TLS request first validates that the server's certificate exactly matches the bundle's certificate.

For some apps, Certificate Pinning may be impossible to do. If your app allows users to enter in their own domain names to connect to services, then you have no opportunity to embed that certificate. However, if your app is intended to connect to a known server, or set of servers, you have all the information you need to guarantee that client is indeed talking directly to the server and without a man in the middle eavesdropping.

diligence_annotations.check_description: iOS Keychain entries are montiored during dynamic analysis. For this check, instances of the password were searched across monitored entries.
diligence_annotations.remediation: For highly sensitive data, it is recommended to avoid the use of the keychain. Instead, rely upon the user to enter application passphrases when the application starts, or with encryption keys sent from the server after a user authenticates.

remediations.remediation_tip: For highly sensitive data, it is recommended to avoid the use of the keychain. Instead, rely upon the user to enter application passphrases when the application starts, or with encryption keys sent from the server after a user authenticates.

diligence_annotations.remediation: For highly sensitive data, it is recommended to avoid the use of the keychain. Instead, rely upon the user to enter application passphrases when the application starts, or with encryption keys sent from the server after a user authenticates.

remediations.remediation_tip: For highly sensitive data, it is recommended to avoid the use of the keychain. Instead, rely upon the user to enter application passphrases when the application starts, or with encryption keys sent from the server after a user authenticates.

diligence_annotations.app_description:
Stay connected with your financial goals – anytime, anywhere – with our Edward Jones app. 

Your financial information is at your fingertips with features allowing you to:

  •	View your account holdings, performance, activity and more
  •	Connect accounts to view balances held outside of Edward Jones
  •	Track progress toward your goals
  •	Message and share documents with your Edward Jones team
  •	Deposit checks and transfer funds
  •	View and sign documents related to your Edward Jones accounts

Also, security is built in to ensure your information is protected.
diligence_annotations.app_release_notes: This update includes minor bug fixes and improvements to the user experience.
diligence_annotations.check_description: Debug logs are generally designed to be used to detect and correct flaws in an application. These logs can leak sensitive information that may help an attacker create a more powerful attack. In this test, ASL messages are analyzed for existence of sensitive user or application data.
diligence_annotations.remediation: Avoid outputting sensitive information to system logs. The application was found to include in system log files pieces of sensitive information belonging to the test user. It is recommended that the application not output any sensitive information belonging to the test user or to the application itself to log files in order to prevent that information from being compromised by an attacker in possession and control of the device on which the application is installed and running.

remediations.remediation_tip: Avoid outputting sensitive information to system logs. The application was found to include in system log files pieces of sensitive information belonging to the test user. It is recommended that the application not output any sensitive information belonging to the test user or to the application itself to log files in order to prevent that information from being compromised by an attacker in possession and control of the device on which the application is installed and running.

diligence_annotations.app_release_notes: This update includes minor bug fixes and improvements to the user experience.
diligence_annotations.check_description: Searches for sensitive data that can be intercepted over the network due to improper certificate validation and/or hostname verification. Sensitive data currently includes Username, Password, GPS Coordinates, Wifi Mac Address, IMEI, Device Serial Number, and Phone number. This is related to the Hostname Verification issue.
diligence_annotations.remediation:
While SSL/TLS was observed to protect the applications sensitive data in transit, it is recommended to properly validate the SSL/TLS certificate to ensure it is signed by a trusted certificate authority (CA) as well as contains the correct hostname.

An even more secure approach is to use Certificate Pinning to mitigate the possibility of SSL/TLS weaknesses. Certificate Pinning is making sure the client checks the server's certificate against a known copy of that certificate. Simply bundle your server's certificate inside your application, and make sure any SSL/TLS request first validates that the server's certificate exactly matches the bundle's certificate.

For some apps, Certificate Pinning may be impossible to do. If your app allows users to enter in their own domain names to connect to services, then you have no opportunity to embed that certificate. However, if your app is intended to connect to a known server, or set of servers, you have all the information you need to guarantee that client is indeed talking directly to the server and without a man in the middle eavesdropping.

remediations.remediation_tip:
While SSL/TLS was observed to protect the applications sensitive data in transit, it is recommended to properly validate the SSL/TLS certificate to ensure it is signed by a trusted certificate authority (CA) as well as contains the correct hostname.

An even more secure approach is to use Certificate Pinning to mitigate the possibility of SSL/TLS weaknesses. Certificate Pinning is making sure the client checks the server's certificate against a known copy of that certificate. Simply bundle your server's certificate inside your application, and make sure any SSL/TLS request first validates that the server's certificate exactly matches the bundle's certificate.

For some apps, Certificate Pinning may be impossible to do. If your app allows users to enter in their own domain names to connect to services, then you have no opportunity to embed that certificate. However, if your app is intended to connect to a known server, or set of servers, you have all the information you need to guarantee that client is indeed talking directly to the server and without a man in the middle eavesdropping.

diligence_annotations.app_release_notes: This update includes minor bug fixes and improvements to the user experience.
diligence_annotations.check_description:
Traffic is analyzed to determine if any sensitive data is transmitted insecurely over the network without encryption.

For this check, instances of the ADID were searched across any intercepted traffic.
diligence_annotations.remediation:
Enforce the use of SSL/TLS for all transport channels in which sensitive information, session tokens, or other sensitive data is going to be communicated to a backend API or web service.

Properly validate the SSL/TLS certificate to ensure it is signed by a trusted certificate authority (CA) as well as contains the correct hostname.

An even more secure approach is to use Certificate Pinning to mitigate the possibility of SSL/TLS weaknesses. Certificate Pinning is making sure the client checks the server's certificate against a known copy of that certificate. Simply bundle your server's certificate inside your application, and make sure any SSL/TLS request first validates that the server's certificate exactly matches the bundle's certificate.

For some apps, Certificate Pinning may be impossible to do. If your app allows users to enter in their own domain names to connect to services, then you have no opportunity to embed that certificate. However, if your app is intended to connect to a known server, or set of servers, you have all the information you need to guarantee that client is indeed talking directly to the server and without a man in the middle eavesdropping.

remediations.remediation_tip:
Enforce the use of SSL/TLS for all transport channels in which sensitive information, session tokens, or other sensitive data is going to be communicated to a backend API or web service.

Properly validate the SSL/TLS certificate to ensure it is signed by a trusted certificate authority (CA) as well as contains the correct hostname.

An even more secure approach is to use Certificate Pinning to mitigate the possibility of SSL/TLS weaknesses. Certificate Pinning is making sure the client checks the server's certificate against a known copy of that certificate. Simply bundle your server's certificate inside your application, and make sure any SSL/TLS request first validates that the server's certificate exactly matches the bundle's certificate.

For some apps, Certificate Pinning may be impossible to do. If your app allows users to enter in their own domain names to connect to services, then you have no opportunity to embed that certificate. However, if your app is intended to connect to a known server, or set of servers, you have all the information you need to guarantee that client is indeed talking directly to the server and without a man in the middle eavesdropping.

remediations.remediation_tip:
Enforce the use of SSL/TLS for all transport channels in which sensitive information, session tokens, or other sensitive data is going to be communicated to a backend API or web service.

Properly validate the SSL/TLS certificate to ensure it is signed by a trusted certificate authority (CA) as well as contains the correct hostname.

An even more secure approach is to use Certificate Pinning to mitigate the possibility of SSL/TLS weaknesses. Certificate Pinning is making sure the client checks the server's certificate against a known copy of that certificate. Simply bundle your server's certificate inside your application, and make sure any SSL/TLS request first validates that the server's certificate exactly matches the bundle's certificate.

For some apps, Certificate Pinning may be impossible to do. If your app allows users to enter in their own domain names to connect to services, then you have no opportunity to embed that certificate. However, if your app is intended to connect to a known server, or set of servers, you have all the information you need to guarantee that client is indeed talking directly to the server and without a man in the middle eavesdropping.
